name: 2,2'-[Oxybis(ethane-2,1-diyloxy)]diethanol
Reason: The basic unit for consideration here is ethanol, which has a melting point of -114.1°C. The compound has several -O- (ether) groups, which tend to lower the melting point slightly compared to a hydrocarbon chain because of lessened van der Waals forces, but the hydroxyl (-OH) groups contribute to hydrogen bonding, which significantly raises the melting point. As we have four -OH groups, this effect is amplified. Ether linkage: -20°C (each) because they make the molecule more rigid and less compact, but this is offset by hydrogen bonding. Hydroxyl group: +60°C (each) due to strong hydrogen bonding between molecules.
Test (Predicted reason):
- Basic unit, ethane has a melting point of -172°C. 
- Each ether linkage (–O–) is expected to increase the melting point due to the increase in molecular weight and the ability to form dipole-dipole interactions, estimated at +20°C per ether linkage. 
- Each hydroxyl group (–OH) can form hydrogen bonds, which significantly increases the melting point, estimated at +40°C per hydroxyl group. 
- The presence of two hydroxyl groups on the same molecule can lead to intramolecular hydrogen bonding, which may slightly reduce the increase in melting point due to intermolecular hydrogen bonding, estimated at -5°C for the intramolecular effect. 
- The molecule has a large molecular weight and a complex structure, which can lead to a higher melting point due to increased van der Waals forces, estimated at +10°C.
